title: Market Resiliency and the June CPI | Bloomberg Surveillance

Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts,
radio, news.
[Music]
This is the Bloomberg Surveillance
Podcast. Catch us live weekdays at 7
a.m. Eastern on Apple CarPlay or Android
Auto with the Bloomberg Business App.
Listen on demand wherever you get your
podcasts or watch us live on YouTube.
She's more important than the secretary
of treasury. Constance Hunter joins now
from EIU. Constance, you take your
inflation guesstimate to two decimal
points. Can you do that? Can we actually
guess to two decimal points on a change
in inflation?
Well, you bring up a really great point,
Tom, and especially with regards to
goods. What we've discovered is that we
really don't know the price elasticity
of demand of a number of these goods
that are going to be impacted. So, we're
triangulating all sorts of different
data sources um and really kind of
trying to get under the hood. But your
point is well taken, right? What what is
even the point of going out to two
decimal points uh if you uh if you have
this level of uncertainty? Nevertheless,
um we try to be as precise as possible
so we can learn from uh our actions.
Do you do you see substitution of
products going on because of tariffs?
Oh, absolutely. I mean, and and I think
what'll be interesting to see is is
again how price sensitive are consumers
once these price increases really start
to feed through. Let's remember we had
an extraordinary amount of front-loading
um in the in the beginning of the year
and and really at the end of the fourth
quarter last year where consumers
pre-bought and suppliers pre-bought
ahead of these tariffs, right? And so
we're still waiting for that pig in the
python to move its way through.
Constance, when do you think we'll see
that? Is that something that we're going
to see maybe today or is we're not going
to see any inflation impact if there is
any and a lot of folks say that there
may not. Is that something we may have
to wait till the fall to see maybe in
the data?
You know, I think you're right, Paul. I
think it's I think it's taking a lot
longer and and what we see from some
some alternative sources like Cavalo,
for example, um which really it does
work on on uh real time prices and they
gather information from four different
retailers. We can guess who some of
those retailers are. um Amazon, Walmart.
Um and when you think about Amazon and
the the troves of PhD economists they
have working on how to price goods,
right? They probably have better
information about the price elasticity
than anybody else right now in the US
economy. Um and what they show is
actually that domestic prices while they
increased in the beginning have really
leveled off. So domestic suppliers are
aware of that price sensitivity I think
and are keeping their prices competitive
so that they can gain market share.
C just to get narrow here 45 seconds.
Auto insurance is 3% of our inflation
picture. Is there anybody listening
who's paying less in auto insurance? I
don't think so. Constance.
No. when you talked earlier about all
the the the flash floods and and rain
that you know the New York area
experienced over the last 24 hours and
that destroys automobiles. If you get
stuck in a flash flood, your car is
totaled, right? Um and so we look at the
incidence of perils and they're
increasing and then what happens is that
that gets transferred to the entire auto
market, right? Everybody autoinsures
price. so that they make up losses in
areas where they're experiencing higher
cat catastrophes.
We're trying to give constants 32
seconds here to look at the
Yeah. Plenty of time.
Constance with DIU. In the 90 second
glance, you've had constants. What do
you see?
Well, it's not showing up in goods,
right? If you go to the commodities less
food and energy, you're not seeing it in
apparel, which was down month over
month. you're not seeing it in new
vehicles, which um you know, it was also
down. Used cars and trucks have a little
more complicated uh pricing in them. Um
medical care commodities were up 0.6
month over month, but you're really not
seeing that. Tobacco and smoking
products are up 0.8, but uh I don't know
if that constitutes a trend. Um and I I
you know I don't know how much we import
of China.
But the answer is K is before we let you
go. I don't mean to interrupt but this
is too important. After hearing from
Bessant then Hunter the president's
going to come out and say show me the
inflation and tariffs. Right.
Of course he is. Yes. That's that is the
issue. And and the reality is it is not
in the current data. We do know of
course that inflation is somewhat of a
lagging indicator. Right. If you're a
firm, you're you're going to wait as
long as you can to raise prices because
you don't want to lose market share. So,
we just need to keep in mind this is a
lagging indicator.
Is there a scenario where the companies
actually by and large do take it in the
margin and we don't see it necessarily
at the consumer level? Is that a a
scenario? I know a lot of folks are
suggesting that might be the case.
Well, there was an interesting article.
I think it was in the Wall Street
Journal from my morning scan of the
news. how Levis's is reducing the number
of SKUs in order to manage their costs
so that they don't have to pass on the
price increases, right? So they're
they're um they're reducing the the
variety of things that they're
producing. And so I think firms are
really, you know, when you think about
the data and analytics that's been
deployed over the last 6 years in
companies, firms have a lot more
capacity to control their supply chain
and to control their product mix and
we're seeing some of that productivity
gain from that those data enhancements
coming to bear as firms try to manage
through this.
Cass, thank you so much. Just wonderful
to have you here uh at 8:30 for the
National Inflation Report. Constance
Hunter with EIU.
You're listening to the Bloomberg
Surveillance Podcast. Catch us live
weekday afternoons from 7 to 10:00 a.m.
Eastern.
Listen on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto
with the Bloomberg Business App or watch
us live on YouTube.
We turn to banks. It's been Helter
Skelter today with the Treasury
Secretary. This is a more important
conversation for global Wall Street.
Allison Williams joins us with Bloomberg
Intelligence. Allison, the way I read it
as a complete hack is we go, there's
four big banks. No, there's JP Morgan
and there's these three other banks. Am
I off the mark?
Well, there's JP Morgan. I always say
covering JP Morgan is like covering, you
know, four big companies, right? Or um,
you know, depending on how they they've
done their division. I guess it's three
big companies now. So um you know really
the net interest income guidance very
strong about 600 million upside to the
ratios were sick. I went back and forth
with Valerie Titel in London. They did a
tangible equity of 20% plus. Am I right?
Cityroup's half that.
Uh you are right. I mean if you look at
you know so if you look at Croup it's a
very different story. Right. So Cityroup
is still in a story of transition. Um,
we've been talking about that
transition, as we say, ever since, uh,
Sandy built the house. It's been being
taken apart and I think Jane Frasier is
making a lot of tough decisions there
and really solid quarter out of Croup as
well. Um, you know, they're upping their
net interest income guidance. Their
fixed income trading up 20%. So that's
it. That, you know, JP Morgan and Wells
were up 13 to 14%. You know, Cityroup
has an amazing rates and currencies
trading business as you know, Paul and
that is really where the strength is
this quarter. That's where the
volatility is and they are really um
executing in that business. Uh again,
cordet interest income going up for both
of those banks. Wells Fargo a little
softer, but Wells Fargo is looking at
the overall number. Keep in mind that
there's core net interest income and
then there's a number that includes uh
trading. And so the trading net interest
income tends to be offset in fees I
think for but from a headline
perspective people are sort of going to
be less positive on those Wells Fargo
results. Wells Fargo also not getting um
this huge benefit. So as I said they saw
some growth in fixed income trading but
well um you know JP Morgan and city much
stronger in those businesses. JP Morgan
delivering a billion dollars of upside
uh in their uh trading and fee. I
haven't done the calculation yet for
cityroup, but the trends also better for
city.
Are what are the banks saying about loan
origination? Are they writing loans? We
were just talking to Hugh Van Cenus and
Oliver Wyman about private credit and
I just think back to my Chase Manhattan
days. We were killing it doing the
leverage loan business, making money
upfront, making money on the spread,
syndicating by risk out to every other
bank around the country.
What are they making loans these days?
So, so they are making loans. I mean,
you know, that that the the card
business, which was probably not your
concern back then or now, but yeah, the
card business is is very profitable for
these banks and that's where the loan
growth has been. And again, that's
benefiting city and JP Morgan. We have
seen a little bit of pickup in the
commercial numbers in the, you know, in
the Fed data. We're going to hear what
Bank America says tomorrow on that. I
think with regard to privates, you know,
it it is a change, but I think if you
look at, for example, Goldman's
business, so Paul, you know, Goldman,
you know, their merchant banking
business, you know that they, you know,
back in the day made a lot of money from
making these proprietary investments.
Vulkar uh rule came along and said,
"Please don't do that on your balance
sheet." By the way, investors don't like
the balance sheet, right? Because when
you make those kind of investments and
you're recording gains, people don't
really give you a lot of credit because
they view them as volatile, etc. But you
have someone like Goldman who's now
said, I'm going to be an alternative
asset manager. And now instead of
putting my balance sheet at risk, I'm
going to, you know, take the client's
money. So, and I'm going to earn fees.
And investors like that. They like asset
management. It's a high multiple
business. And so, it's a higher return
on equity business. And that's been a
longterm story, Goldman.
So I think the banks are fine and that
so that's a Goldman specific, but I
think all the banks are doing that.
Okay, I want to go to the gossip of the
moment, folks. Out in the Hamptons over
a beverage of her choice. Allison
Williams is getting hammered by fancy
people over the reorg under Mary Erdos
at JP Morgan. They're first of all, I'm
going to say they're the most successful
bank asset manager, the only one really
competing with Black Rockck and the
others. So Mary's built a franchise and
now they're saying geography doesn't
matter anymore. The Wall Street Journal
had this great summary of it. Explain to
us how JP Morgan and Mary Erdos is
blowing up asset management, private
wealth.
Well, I think that, you know, Mary Erdos
is first and foremost thoughtful about
the talent across her business and, you
know, is is consistently talking about
the strength they have as an active
manager. Um, but one of the more
interesting uh things that Eric
Baltunis, as as you know, who's the
expert on EATF, has been talking about
is that they are really gaining share in
the active ETF business. And so, um, so
that's not your that's not your
question, but that is something that
that I want to highlight that I think is
something happening over there.
We're we're in a bull market. They're
minting more money than God. And JP
Morgan is saying, "We got a problem. We
got to blow up private wealth
management." Why are they blowing it up
and what's the goal?
Well, again, I I don't know. I think
that Mary Erdos is a very thoughtful
leader and I think that again, it's it's
sort of like as we're as we're going
through the future, we've been through a
long period of what uh we call US
exceptionalism. Y
um but I think that JP Morgan has always
uh focused on the world at large,
focused on emerging markets, focused on
um these different growth opportunities.
And I think it's just a way and and by
the way JP Morgan I think is always as I
alluded to earlier, you know, looking at
things differently. When you're a global
organization, you have products and you
have regions. I think sometimes you have
to find a way to focus on on both. And I
again I just I go back to the fact that
they're very focused on talent and I
think that you know they're thoughtful
about the way they run their business.
We're seeing so many good results coming
out of these US global banks. It just
makes me think next week we're going to
hear from the European banks and they're
just nowhere nowhere relative to where
the US banks are. When will Europe say
we need to allow consolidation here? I
mean I they're they fall so far behind
every single year it seems. Is that not
an issue for them?
They do. And I think that I mean I think
that the the biggest change Paul over
the last you know let's call it decade
or a couple of decades right time flies
is that you know first of all the US has
benefited from a virtuous cycle of
having sort of a better economy for a
long period of time but really you know
they've they've benefited from the
virtuous cycle of investment. they had
the money to invest, they invested the
money. So that's led to better revenue,
better market share, etc. Whereas I
think for the Europeans, you know, they
tried to sort of cut their way to
profitability and that ended up um you
know, as you know, invest in banking and
trading, these are not businesses where
you go bargain shopping, right? And so I
think that they didn't invest um that
hurt them. Uh they've had to exit
businesses, etc. But it's difficult
because each of the
everyone agrees we really should
consolidate merge some of the best
together but no one wants to be the
seller. Everyone wants to be the buyer.
Everybody wants the the champion in
their home market.
Come on. There's a price.
That's the that's price.
Are we at the point where the shock of
the later this year quickly here Allison
is we get one big industry roll up
because they find price and is the
sellers say enough? Let's go. I mean I
you know we could have had this
conversation 14 times a million you know
I just think that those political
sensitivities
it's it's very difficult and it's hard
to say
right
what ever would would would change their
mind
okay what do we see tomorrow
things that make sense on paper you know
politics get in the way
10 seconds tomorrow Goldman Sachs Morgan
Stanley they do better than good
I you know based on the trading and fee
numbers we saw today based on all the
trends we saw in the quarter. We think
that it's going to be a a a solid
quarter for trading. We're going to want
to hear what their what their CEO
clients are saying with regard to the
investment packing.
Thank you so much for this brief
particularly on you know where we are on
uh the reorg of JP Morgan in private
management and of course over to the
other banks particularly city bank here.
This is the Bloomberg Surveillance
Podcast. Listen live each weekday
starting at 7 a.m. Eastern on Apple
CarPlay and Android Auto with the
Bloomberg Business App. You can also
listen live on Amazon Alexa from our
flagship New York station. Just say,
"Alexa, play Bloomberg 11:30."
We're going to get the private credit
here with Huan Stenzas. Paul's going to
bring that in, but I got to first do an
audible here, folks. It's a surveillance
audible in a two-hour conversation uh
with Huon Stenzas. You go, "Okay, where'
this guy come from?" And it's not Oliver
Wyman or his work with the Bank of
England with at the time Governor Carney
or he did this as UBS da da da da Years
ago like think Queen Anne Huon Stenis
was at Morgan Stanley and he was
absolutely definitive on EU finance.
Joining us now with Oliver Wyman. Huon
Stenis audible. I saw the French tresor,
not the oat hue, the trussor roll over
yesterday with acceleration. How fragile
is French debt given Mr. Trump's
shenanigans?
Oh, Tom, thanks for having me on again.
Look, I think there's a lot of pressure
from investors for on the on the French
situation. Um, a lot of fixed income
investors are struggling with the lack
of debt consolidation. And look, you
know, let's play the history here, Tom.
You know, I think the French throughout
uh the last 30 years have somewhat
struggled with reigning in public debt.
In fact, if you go back to 198183,
you know, actually meter had to do a
huge pivot because he just wasn't
controlling the public debts back there.
And so, I think there's there's real
pressure here. And look, the fact the
spreads already trading outside Portugal
and Spain, and there's a lot of debate
about whether trade outside Italy and
Greece tells you how stressed and and
unhelp nervous folk are.
The jargon he's he's all jargon. I mean,
he was at the state dinner and he
brought the conversation to a halt uh
with his jargon. What he's saying there
is French credits trading worser folks
in Portugal, Greece, and all here. One
final question on this. I'm beginning to
see real yields, inflation adjusted
yields in Europe come up as well. Can
President Trump with his tariff debate
pull up EU real yields to bring Europe
to a standstill?
It's a great question. It's certainly
possible. I think look isn't the issue
with tariffs at the moment that uh the
short-term pain is not there and it's a
question more about how it impacts
investments and the longerterm business
and just like you've seen the resilience
in the states you're seeing real
resilience in the European earnings and
particularly the opening of the fiscal
uh debt. So, I'm not sure that it would
necessarily drag it up uh immediately,
but I think that tension over a 1 2 3ear
period, that's where you're going to
start seeing is there going to be more
friction in the system from lack of
competitiveness. And let's hope
certainly by then we're going to see a
deal. So, I'm not as convinced on that,
but you know, anything's possible. You
were starting to hear from the big banks
uh today and one of the areas of uh
questioning for the banks will be kind
of how they view private credit visa v
their core lending business. How do you
guys view what has been a just a
phenomenal growth story on global Wall
Street which is private credit?
Oh look, so uh I think the private
credit train continues and as we've
discussed many times, you know, that
sector is growing 20 to 25% compound
because it's not just about leverage
lending and mid-market lending. It's
also now about replacing investment
grade either through asset back lending.
So you know, so like private
securitizations or it's going for these
jumbo deals, you know, these really
large complex deals. And under current
bank regulations, if it's risky, if it's
very large or very complex, it goes to
the private markets rather than the
public. So I think there's two two games
here. I think the first is the banks are
clearly fighting back and you saw the
news from one of the big banks yesterday
which you ran showing a new group to try
and come up with solutions for more
complex deals. Maybe the bank takes
part, maybe it slices up and gives part
to private credit, but the banks are
very much back. But I think the other
story, and I think you'll see it through
this earning season, is banks love steep
yield curves. And so the net interest
income for the banks, I think, will
continue to beat and beat and beat
because these steep curves will
translate through to higher earnings.
And therefore, even though they're
seeding ground to private credit, the
core engines are still doing really
well.
So Hugh, for the private credit
business, are there opportunities for
retail investors to get exposure to this
asset class?
Y this is a great question. So we've
been digging into this. So there's been
a two and a halffold increase in the
investments by wealthy in private credit
in the last three years. That's four
times faster than from traditional
institutional investors. And we think
something like $350 billion or about 12%
of private credit assets now come from
the wealthy. Now the wealthy though it's
still the very it's the ultra wealthy
and one of the biggest areas of
innovation in partnerships new products
is trying to think about expanding this
to a much broader range of clients
through you know evergreen funds and you
know just one stat um evergreen funds
are probably the single fastest growing
part of the investment universe at the
moment um interval grunds are growing
70% from a low base so I think this is
an area where there's there's quite a
lot of room to to run uh from Yeah,
with us. Huan Cenis with Oliver Wyman.
He's too modest. Let me put it to you.
It's a It's a really I hate him. There's
a 21page document, Oliver Wyman. Private
credit is reshaping wealth portfolios.
Get it through Oliver uh Wyman. We
protect the copyright of all of our
guests, Hugh Vanas, Ben Phillips, Laura
Watkin, and Parth Agarwal as well.
What's the risk factor here, a wise one?
Is it too much money chasing too few
private credit opportunities? Is that
the credit quality is going to go down?
Is the IRR gonna see how I did that?
It's impressive. As I'll get out, what's
the major risk factor here?
Uh, look, it's great. Well, look, I I'd
say so in the ne so near-term, the
biggest threat is just too much money
chasing and credit spreads continue to
compress and compress. And look, we've
already gone from, you know, if you were
trying to buy a single A private credit
bond two years ago, you might be getting
two 2% more than a public single A. Last
year, it's probably 150 to 175 basis
over basis points over. Today, it's
probably only a point. So, it's probably
the the excess spread is probably halfed
in less than 24 months. And so there
might be if there's a lot of money
coming through. So therefore the
constraint is really about originating
more assets. And so you're seeing more
deals with private credit team up with
banks for partnerships but also looking
to generate their own assets. And I
think that's the gate for me. If they
don't originate enough assets then the
spreads will will compress. I think
longer term clearly there's always going
to be a credit cycle and so that you
know and there'll be some good decisions
and bad decisions but I think at the
moment it's the weight of money. Hugh, I
mean the the dollars are getting just
really substantial there over the last
decade or so. Um, we're starting to get
more and more retail exposure there.
Does there need to be some type of
regulation on the private credit
business, do you think?
So, I think it depends what kind of
regulation. So, I don't see the sector
as systemic. I mean, let's remember u um
banks get regulated partly because they
hold everyone's deposits, but also um
they're very leveraged. And so when
credit leaves a bank, which maybe is 10
times levered, maybe going to an
institutional account, which may be zero
to one times levered, less leverage
means it's less risky uh when when you
hit a speed bump. Um so I don't see it
systemic. But the more you put private
credit into retail portfolios, the more
that then you know the SEC and and
regulators looking at the products and
protecting investors will need to think
about is this the right product? Have we
got regular marks? You know, and I think
we discussed this last time I was in New
York, the pricing convention. So, the
way you think about pricing private
credit, you can't just do it once a
quarter. You do it every month and if
not more frequently. So, there's a lot
of regulatory stuff which we'll need to
play catch up.
I promised Dan Tanibal I'd read your
private credit report. Hugh, I'll get a
pimps in my hand and read that this
weekend. Hugh vonstein is definitive on
private credit with Oliver Wyman.
This is the Bloomberg Surveillance
Podcast. Listen live each weekday
starting at 7 a.m. Eastern on Apple
CarPlay and Android Auto with the
Bloomberg Business App.
You can also watch us live every weekday
on YouTube and always on the Bloomberg
terminal. We're not going to turn this
into a history lesson, but the bottom
line is at LSE in the 50s, Carl Pauper
sat with a young student named George
Soros and said, "The way we think about
history, the way we digest past tense
data is maybe not as productive as it
could be with something called
reflexivity, which is a different
approach. If AI is about a large
language model data dump, how are we
going to move artificial intelligence
onto what Soros and Popper were talking
about?
That's a great question. First of all,
thank you for having me on the show. I
think as what we're seeing currently,
what is really exciting about the
technology that we're witnessing right
in front of us is that it has this
capability to digest huge amounts of
data and start to make sense of it, help
us make sense of it. And I think that we
have always looked to the past to try to
understand the future because that's the
only data that we had,
right?
And what is different this time versus
before is that we seem to have been
accumulating more and more data but
didn't have increased bandwidth to
process it.
In my mind, AI is going to resolve this.
Okay, AI is going to resolve it, but
it's just nothing more than a richer,
deeper back test. Everybody did back
tests on a difference equation. We went
back to T minus one or T minus 20
whatever is AI going to change how
global Wall Street the pros listening to
the show how they back test it is going
to change it because actually I'll I'll
let you know that the experience that we
have had so reflexity platform is used
by a number of top hundrants and what we
have found as they start to incorporate
this into their workflow is that they
are amazed by the speed with which the
system is able to answer their questions
by going straight to the data. In fact,
often they run out of questions because
you were not used to being able to tap
into the data so powerfully and so
quickly. And so we seem to now be
limited only by our imagination. So the
way I think about AI helping investors
on Wall Street is giving them this
superpower where they can keep thinking
about scenarios that could unfold and
have the AI back that up or dispute it
through the data. It's a very objective
arbiter. Can you give us and this is so
new to so many of us, our listeners, our
viewers. What is a typical query that
you would get from an investor client
that maybe AI could be helpful with?
Well, it started with things that were
extremely basic in nature. Somebody
might just say like, oh, you know, I'd
like to really understand if when
somebody talks about the inverted yield
curve, how accurate has that actually
been in predicting recessions? It then
became a lot more complex when you might
say, "Look at all of financials for a
specific company, be it Tesla,
Microsoft, JP Morgan, whatever. Tell me
what is the market not appreciating?"
And suddenly it's pulling together
things it's able to glean from analyst
reports, news outlets, and financials
and say, "Well, actually, here are some
parts of the business that are growing
extremely fast, but get no mention from
the analysts." And so you could have a
rerating. The dream here is that, and
this is what Reflexivity purports to do,
is if you were the first to know that
AWS was going to be a big deal for
Amazon, you would have made a lot of
money. Wow. So
I I I this is such an amazing part of
the investment process. How are your
clients using it today? I mean, how is
that evolving? because I'm assuming this
is an education process for some pretty
smart investors, some savvy investors,
but maybe they don't understand the
logic behind artificial intelligence.
How are they using it today and how do
you want them to use it?
Honestly, our first advice to the
pioneering clients that come to us and
start using it and there have been an
increasing number in the past few weeks
is just dip their toes into it. Try it.
I think trial and error is very
important because I think working with
AI is unlike any other software that you
would have used before, right? Um where
does it get data? How does it calculate?
How does it reason and so on. Once you
get the hang of it, however, it becomes
extremely exciting and you can see
people just get engaged with it.
Okay. You grew up in the millu of
Harvard, MIT and all the fancy people up
in Boston. Black Scholes came out and I
I never met Fischer Black to my great
regret. He died tragically early. But
what a joy I've had in discussing Myron
Scholes and picking up the pieces of
How does a modeling that's new wrapped
around reflexivity? How does this tested
model work given substantial leverage
shocks the discontinuities that are
brought out by leverage as a pro would
use? So again, I think here the
calculations that the system will do
fall back on the traditional statistical
methods. It's not reinventing the way
you're calculating things or the way
you're calculating correlations.

She's more important than the secretary of treasury.
Constance Hunter joins now from EIU.
Constance, you take your inflation guesstimate to two decimal points.
Can you do that?
Can we actually guess to two decimal points on a change in inflation?
Well, you bring up a really great point, Tom, and especially with regards to goods.
What we've discovered is that we really don't know the price elasticity of demand of a number of these goods that are going to be impacted.
So, we're triangulating all sorts of different data sources um and really kind of trying to get under the hood.
But your point is well taken, right?
What what is even the point of going out to two decimal points uh if you uh if you have this level of uncertainty?
Nevertheless, um we try to be as precise as possible so we can learn from uh our actions.
Do you do you see substitution of products going on because of tariffs?
Oh, absolutely.
I mean, and and I think what'll be interesting to see is is again how price sensitive are consumers once these price increases really start to feed through.
Let's remember we had an extraordinary amount of front-loading um in the in the beginning of the year and and really at the end of the fourth quarter last year where consumers pre-bought and suppliers pre-bought ahead of these tariffs, right?
And so we're still waiting for that pig in the python to move its way through.
Constance, when do you think we'll see that?
Is that something that we're going to see maybe today or is we're not going to see any inflation impact if there is any and a lot of folks say that there may not.
Is that something we may have to wait till the fall to see maybe in the data?
You know, I think you're right, Paul.
I think it's I think it's taking a lot longer and and what we see from some some alternative sources like Cavalo, for example, um which really it does work on on uh real time prices and they gather information from four different retailers.
We can guess who some of those retailers are.
Um Amazon, Walmart.
Um and when you think about Amazon and the the troves of PhD economists they have working on how to price goods, right?
They probably have better information about the price elasticity than anybody else right now in the US economy.
Um and what they show is actually that domestic prices while they increased in the beginning have really leveled off.
So domestic suppliers are aware of that price sensitivity I think and are keeping their prices competitive so that they can gain market share.
C just to get narrow here 45 seconds.
Auto insurance is 3% of our inflation picture.
Is there anybody listening who's paying less in auto insurance?
I don't think so.
Constance.
No.
When you talked earlier about all the the flash floods and and rain that you know the New York area experienced over the last 24 hours and that destroys automobiles.
If you get stuck in a flash flood, your car is totaled, right?
Um and so we look at the incidence of perils and they're increasing and then what happens is that that gets transferred to the entire auto market, right?
Everybody autoinsures price.
So that they make up losses in areas where they're experiencing higher catastrophes.
We're trying to give constants 32 seconds here to look at the
Yeah.
Plenty of time.
Constance with DIU.
In the 90 second glance, you've had constants.
What do you see?
Well, it's not showing up in goods, right?
If you go to the commodities less food and energy, you're not seeing it in apparel, which was down month over month.
You're not seeing it in new vehicles, which um you know, it was also down.
Used cars and trucks have a little more complicated uh pricing in them.
Um medical care commodities were up 0.6 month over month, but you're really not seeing that.
Tobacco and smoking products are up 0.8, but uh I don't know if that constitutes a trend.
Um and I I you know I don't know how much we import of China.
But the answer is K is before we let you go.
I don't mean to interrupt but this is too important.
After hearing from Bessant then Hunter the president's going to come out and say show me the inflation and tariffs.
Right.
Of course he is.
Yes.
That's that is the issue.
And and the reality is it is not in the current data.
We do know of course that inflation is somewhat of a lagging indicator.
Right.
If you're a firm, you're you're going to wait as long as you can to raise prices because you don't want to lose market share.
So, we just need to keep in mind this is a lagging indicator.
Is there a scenario where the companies actually by and large do take it in the margin and we don't see it necessarily at the consumer level?
Is that a a scenario?
I know a lot of folks are suggesting that might be the case.
Well, there was an interesting article.
I think it was in the Wall Street Journal from my morning scan of the news.
How Levis's is reducing the number of SKUs in order to manage their costs so that they don't have to pass on the price increases, right?
So they're they're um they're reducing the the variety of things that they're producing.
And so I think firms are really, you know, when you think about the data and analytics that's been deployed over the last 6 years in companies, firms have a lot more capacity to control their supply chain and to control their product mix and we're seeing some of that productivity gain from that those data enhancements coming to bear as firms try to manage through this.
Cass, thank you so much.
Just wonderful to have you here uh at 8:30 for the National Inflation Report.
Constance Hunter with EIU.
You're listening to the Bloomberg Surveillance Podcast.
Catch us live weekday afternoons from 7 to 10:00 a.m. Eastern.
Listen on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with the Bloomberg Business App or watch us live on YouTube.
We turn to banks.
It's been Helter Skelter today with the Treasury Secretary.
This is a more important conversation for global Wall Street.
Alison Williams joins us with Bloomberg Intelligence.
Allison, the way I read it as a complete hack is we go, there's four big banks.
No, there's JP Morgan and there's these three other banks.
Am I off the mark?
Well, there's JP Morgan.
I always say covering JP Morgan is like covering, you know, four big companies, right?
Or um, you know, depending on how they they've done their division.
I guess it's three big companies now.
So um you know really the net interest income guidance very strong about 600 million upside to the ratios were sick.
I went back and forth with Valerie Titel in London.
They did a tangible equity of 20% plus.
Am I right?
Citygroup's half that.
Uh you are right.
I mean if you look at you know so if you look at Croup it's a very different story.
Right.
So Citygroup is still in a story of transition.
Um, we've been talking about that transition, as we say, ever since, uh, Sandy built the house.
It's been being taken apart and I think Jane Frasier is making a lot of tough decisions there and really solid quarter out of Croup as well.
Um, you know, they're upping their net interest income guidance.
Their fixed income trading up 20%.
So that's it.
That, you know, JP Morgan and Wells were up 13 to 14%.
You know, Cityroup has an amazing rates and currencies trading business as you know, Paul and that is really where the strength is this quarter.
That's where the volatility is and they are really um executing in that business.
Uh again, cordet interest income going up for both of those banks.
Wells Fargo a little softer, but Wells Fargo is looking at the overall number.
Keep in mind that there's core net interest income and then there's a number that includes uh trading.
And so the trading net interest income tends to be offset in fees I think for but from a headline perspective people are sort of going to be less positive on those Wells Fargo results.
Wells Fargo also not getting um this huge benefit.
So as I said they saw some growth in fixed income trading but well um you know JP Morgan and city much stronger in those businesses.
JP Morgan delivering a billion dollars of upside uh in their uh trading and fee.
I haven't done the calculation yet for cityroup, but the trends also better for city.
Are what are the banks saying about loan origination?
Are they writing loans?
We were just talking to Huw van Steenis and Oliver Wyman about private credit and I just think back to my Chase Manhattan days.
We were killing it doing the leverage loan business, making money upfront, making money on the spread, syndicating by risk out to every other bank around the country.
What are they making loans these days?
So, so they are making loans.
I mean, you know, that that the the card business, which was probably not your concern back then or now, but yeah, the card business is is very profitable for these banks and that's where the loan growth has been.
And again, that's benefiting city and JP Morgan.
We have seen a little bit of pickup in the commercial numbers in the, you know, in the Fed data.
We're going to hear what Bank America says tomorrow on that.
I think with regard to privates, you know, it it is a change, but I think if you look at, for example, Goldman's business, so Paul, you know, Goldman, you know, their merchant banking business, you know that they, you know, back in the day made a lot of money from making these proprietary investments.
Vulkar uh rule came along and said, "Please don't do that on your balance sheet."
By the way, investors don't like the balance sheet, right?
Because when you make those kind of investments and you're recording gains, people don't really give you a lot of credit because they view them as volatile, etc.
But you have someone like Goldman who's now said, I'm going to be an alternative asset manager.
And now instead of putting my balance sheet at risk, I'm going to, you know, take the client's money.
So, and I'm going to earn fees.
And investors like that.
They like asset management.
It's a high multiple business.
And so, it's a higher return on equity business.
And that's been a longterm story, Goldman.
So I think the banks are fine and that so that's a Goldman specific, but I think all the banks are doing that.
Okay, I want to go to the gossip of the moment, folks.
Out in the Hamptons over a beverage of her choice.
Allison Williams is getting hammered by fancy people over the reorg under Mary Erdos at JP Morgan.
They're first of all, I'm going to say they're the most successful bank asset manager, the only one really competing with BlackRock and the others.
So Mary's built a franchise and now they're saying geography doesn't matter anymore.
The Wall Street Journal had this great summary of it.
Explain to us how JP Morgan and Mary Erdos is blowing up asset management, private wealth.
Well, I think that, you know, Mary Erdos is first and foremost thoughtful about the talent across her business and, you know, is is consistently talking about the strength they have as an active manager.
Um, but one of the more interesting uh things that Eric Baltunis, as as you know, who's the expert on EATF, has been talking about is that they are really gaining share in the active ETF business.
And so, um, so that's not your that's not your question, but that is something that that I want to highlight that I think is something happening over there.
We're we're in a bull market.
They're minting more money than God.
And JP Morgan is saying, "We got a problem.
We got to blow up private wealth management."
Why are they blowing it up and what's the goal?
Well, again, I I don't know.
I think that Mary Erdos is a very thoughtful leader and I think that again, it's it's sort of like as we're as we're going through the future, we've been through a long period of what uh we call US exceptionalism.
Y um but I think that JP Morgan has always uh focused on the world at large, focused on emerging markets, focused on um these different growth opportunities.
And I think it's just a way and and by the way JP Morgan I think is always as I alluded to earlier, you know, looking at things differently.
When you're a global organization, you have products and you have regions.
I think sometimes you have to find a way to focus on on both.
And I again I just I go back to the fact that they're very focused on talent and I think that you know they're thoughtful about the way they run their business.
We're seeing so many good results coming out of these US global banks.
It just makes me think next week we're going to hear from the European banks and they're just nowhere nowhere relative to where the US banks are.
When will Europe say we need to allow consolidation here?
I mean I they're they fall so far behind every single year it seems.
Is that not an issue for them?
They do.
And I think that I mean I think that the the biggest change Paul over the last you know let's call it decade or a couple of decades right time flies is that you know first of all the US has benefited from a virtuous cycle of having sort of a better economy for a long period of time but really you know they've they've benefited from the virtuous cycle of investment.
They had the money to invest, they invested the money.
So that's led to better revenue, better market share, etc.
Whereas I think for the Europeans, you know, they tried to sort of cut their way to profitability and that ended up um you know, as you know, invest in banking and trading, these are not businesses where you go bargain shopping, right?
And so I think that they didn't invest um that hurt them.
Uh they've had to exit businesses, etc.
But it's difficult because each of the
everyone agrees we really should consolidate merge some of the best together but no one wants to be the seller.
Everyone wants to be the buyer.
Everybody wants the the champion in their home market.
Come on.
There's a price.
That's the that's price.
Are we at the point where the shock of the later this year quickly here Allison is we get one big industry roll up because they find price and is the sellers say enough?
Let's go.
I mean I you know we could have had this conversation 14 times a million you know I just think that those political sensitivities
it's it's very difficult and it's hard to say
right
what


Ever would change their mind.
Okay, what do we see tomorrow?
Things that make sense on paper, you know, politics get in the way.
10 seconds tomorrow.
Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, they do better than good.
I, you know, based on the trading and fee numbers we saw today, based on all the trends we saw in the quarter, we think that it's going to be a solid quarter for trading.
We're going to want to hear what their CEO clients are saying with regard to the investment packing.
Thank you so much for this brief, particularly on, you know, where we are on the reorg of JPMorgan in private management and of course over to the other banks, particularly Citigroup here.

You can also listen live on Amazon Alexa from our flagship New York station.
Just say, "Alexa, play Bloomberg 11:30."
We're going to get the private credit here with Huw van Steenis.
Paul's going to bring that in, but I got to first do an audible here, folks.
It's a surveillance audible in a two-hour conversation with Huw van Steenis.
You go, "Okay, where's this guy come from?"
And it's not Oliver Wyman or his work with the Bank of England with at the time Governor Carney, or he did this as UBS da da da da years ago, like think Queen Anne.
Huw van Steenis was at Morgan Stanley and he was absolutely definitive on EU finance.
Joining us now with Oliver Wyman.
Huw van Steenis audible.
I saw the French tresor, not the oat hue, the trussor roll over yesterday with acceleration.
How fragile is French debt given Mr. Trump's shenanigans?
Oh, Tom, thanks for having me on again.
Look, I think there's a lot of pressure from investors for on the on the French situation.
Um, a lot of fixed income investors are struggling with the lack of debt consolidation.
And look, you know, let's play the history here, Tom.
You know, I think the French throughout the last 30 years have somewhat struggled with reigning in public debt.
In fact, if you go back to 1981-83, you know, actually Mitterrand had to do a huge pivot because he just wasn't controlling the public debts back there.
And so, I think there's there's real pressure here.
And look, the fact the spreads already trading outside Portugal and Spain, and there's a lot of debate about whether trade outside Italy and Greece tells you how stressed and and unhelp nervous folk are.
The jargon, he's he's all jargon.
I mean, he was at the state dinner and he brought the conversation to a halt with his jargon.
What he's saying there is French credits trading worser folks in Portugal, Greece, and all here.
One final question on this.
I'm beginning to see real yields, inflation adjusted yields in Europe come up as well.
Can President Trump with his tariff debate pull up EU real yields to bring Europe to a standstill?
It's a great question.
It's certainly possible.
I think look isn't the issue with tariffs at the moment that the short-term pain is not there and it's a question more about how it impacts investments and the longer-term business and just like you've seen the resilience in the states, you're seeing real resilience in the European earnings and particularly the opening of the fiscal debt.
So, I'm not sure that it would necessarily drag it up immediately, but I think that tension over a 1, 2, 3-year period, that's where you're going to start seeing is there going to be more friction in the system from lack of competitiveness.
And let's hope certainly by then we're going to see a deal.
So, I'm not as convinced on that, but you know, anything's possible.
You were starting to hear from the big banks today and one of the areas of questioning for the banks will be kind of how they view private credit visa v their core lending business.
How do you guys view what has been a just a phenomenal growth story on global Wall Street which is private credit?
Oh look, so I think the private credit train continues and as we've discussed many times, you know, that sector is growing 20 to 25% compound because it's not just about leverage lending and mid-market lending.
It's also now about replacing investment grade either through asset back lending.
So you know, so like private securitizations or it's going for these jumbo deals, you know, these really large complex deals.
And under current bank regulations, if it's risky, if it's very large or very complex, it goes to the private markets rather than the public.
So I think there's two two games here.
I think the first is the banks are clearly fighting back and you saw the news from one of the big banks yesterday which you ran showing a new group to try and come up with solutions for more complex deals.
Maybe the bank takes part, maybe it slices up and gives part to private credit, but the banks are very much back.
But I think the other story, and I think you'll see it through this earning season, is banks love steep yield curves.
And so the net interest income for the banks, I think, will continue to beat and beat and beat because these steep curves will translate through to higher earnings.
And therefore, even though they're seeding ground to private credit, the core engines are still doing really well.
So Huw, for the private credit business, are there opportunities for retail investors to get exposure to this asset class?
Y, this is a great question.
So we've been digging into this.
So there's been a two and a half-fold increase in the investments by wealthy in private credit in the last three years.
That's four times faster than from traditional institutional investors.
And we think something like $350 billion or about 12% of private credit assets now come from the wealthy.
Now the wealthy though, it's still the very it's the ultra wealthy and one of the biggest areas of innovation in partnerships new products is trying to think about expanding this to a much broader range of clients through you know evergreen funds and you know just one stat um evergreen funds are probably the single fastest growing part of the investment universe at the moment um interval funds are growing 70% from a low base so I think this is an area where there's there's quite a lot of room to to run uh from Yeah, with us.
Huw van Steenis with Oliver Wyman.
He's too modest.
Let me put it to you.
It's a It's a really I hate him.
There's a 21-page document, Oliver Wyman.
Private credit is reshaping wealth portfolios.
Get it through Oliver Wyman.
We protect the copyright of all of our guests, Huw van Steenis, Ben Phillips, Laura Watkin, and Parth Agarwal as well.
What's the risk factor here, a wise one?
Is it too much money chasing too few private credit opportunities?
Is that the credit quality is going to go down?
Is the IRR gonna see how I did that?
It's impressive.
As I'll get out, what's the major risk factor here?
Uh, look, it's great.
Well, look, I I'd say so in the near-term, the biggest threat is just too much money chasing and credit spreads continue to compress and compress.
And look, we've already gone from, you know, if you were trying to buy a single A private credit bond two years ago, you might be getting two 2% more than a public single A.
Last year, it's probably 150 to 175 basis over basis points over.
Today, it's probably only a point.
So, it's probably the the excess spread is probably halfed in less than 24 months.
And so there might be if there's a lot of money coming through.
So therefore the constraint is really about originating more assets.
And so you're seeing more deals with private credit team up with banks for partnerships but also looking to generate their own assets.
And I think that's the gate for me.
If they don't originate enough assets then the spreads will will compress.
I think longer term clearly there's always going to be a credit cycle and so that you know and there'll be some good decisions and bad decisions but I think at the moment it's the weight of money.
Huw, I mean the the dollars are getting just really substantial there over the last decade or so.
Um, we're starting to get more and more retail exposure there.
Does there need to be some type of regulation on the private credit business, do you think?
So, I think it depends what kind of regulation.
So, I don't see the sector as systemic.
I mean, let's remember um banks get regulated partly because they hold everyone's deposits, but also um they're very leveraged.
And so when credit leaves a bank, which maybe is 10 times levered, maybe going to an institutional account, which may be zero to one times levered, less leverage means it's less risky uh when when you hit a speed bump.
